title: How important was the role of war aircraft in the first world war? Is it merely for scouting and demoralizing the opponents? - Quora

response.answer_text: The airplane had only 11 years of life when WW1 started. Aircraft were fragile and engines were underpowered. Their maximum speed would be 100–120 km/h. In order to have sustain they needed 2/3 wings. There were also weight limitations. Radio was also in his infancy so planes weren’t equiped with them. The first aircraft missions in WW1 were reconnaissance missions. Then opposing aircraft started to meet in the skies and pilots would try to shoot their foes with pistols. Later with stronger engines and better projects a plane could already bear 2 crewmen and guns. The rear man was the gunner. Then came the machine gunned plane and the interrupted gear which allowed pilots to shoot through the propeller. The dogfight era started… In 1918 there were already 4 engine bombers like the Handley Page and the Gotta. So the answer is EVOLUTION…

The Recconaisaance aircraft was arguably one of the most important aspects of WW1 technology If was to preveent enemy recce aircraft operating that fighters developed Recce was crucial, it showed where the enemy was concentrating forces ready for an offensive, it identified enemy artillery positions so they could be targetted, it took steroscopic photos of enemy trenches to plot maps
